document.docAuthor: Cock, Matthew J. W. & Congdon, Colin E.
document.masterDocTitle: Observations on the biology of Afrotropical Hesperiidae (Lepidoptera) principally from Kenya. Part 4. Hesperiinae: Aeromachini and Baorini

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Observations on the biology of Afrotropical Hesperiidae (Lepidoptera) principally from Kenya. Part 4. Hesperiinae: Aeromachini and Baorini

subSubSection.paragraph:
The indistinct brown discal band UNH (Figure 19.1 ) makes this species quite distinctive. In the field, the yellowish tibiae and tarsi may also be helpful (Figure 19.1 ). This is a fairly common and widespread member of the genus, found in partially wooded or wooded situations from sea level to at least 1600m in eastern and southeastern Africa.
Sevastopulo ( 1974 )
considered it fairly common in the Makardara Forest, and I have found in both lightly and densely wooded areas from the Kenya coast to western Kenya .

Adults rest quietly on low vegetation for extended periods with their wings closed (Figure 19.1 ), but they will also sunbathe (Figure 19.2 ).
Henning et al . ( 1997 )
describe territorial behaviour based on these perches.
Dickson & Kroon ( 1978 )
consider it a morning species, not normally seen in the afternoons, but we do not have observations to assess this.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 19 . Adult female
Borbo lugens
. 1 , at rest, Kakamega Forest, 16.vi.1991; 2 , female basking, Kisii, 7.viii.1990 (vouchered).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Grasses are the only food plants recorded.
Le Pelley ( 1959 )
records
Panicum trichocladum
as a food plant in Uganda and
Sevastopulo ( 1975 )
lists
P. trichocladum
,
Cenchrus purpureus
(=
Pennisetum purpureum
) and grasses generally from East Africa (although as noted under
B. fatuellus
, this entry appears against both
B. fatuellus
and
B. lugens
, and I assume it applies to both).

Murray ( 1959 )
records
Ehrharta erecta
and
Setaria megaphylla
(= sulcata ) in South Africa , to which
Panicum
( s.l. ) sp. and
Stipa
sp. have been added (G.C. Clark in
Dickson & Kroon 1978
,
Pringle et al . 1994
) as well as
Panicum deustum (
Henning et al . 1997
)
.

Larsen ( 1991 )
and
Ackery et al . ( 1995 )
list
Ehrharta
,
Panicum
,
Stipa
,
Setaria
, and
Cenchrus
(=
Pennisetum
), derived from the above. I have collected caterpillars on
Panicum trichocladum
(several times) and
Megathyrsus maximus
(=
Panicum maximum
); in captivity caterpillars also fed on
Cenchrus trachyphyllus
(=
Pennisetum trachyphyllum
).

The ova in
Figure 20
were laid by a wild caught female from Cottar's Camp, Masai Mara, which was kept in a 58mm diameter plastic pot (
Cock 2010 b
). Ova measure 1.0mm in diameter including the basal flange, and 0.9 without it. They are laid singly according to
Henning et al . ( 1997 )
, and hatch within between 5 days at the Kenya coast (Sevastopulo unpublished) and nine days at Nairobi ( 90 / 22 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 20 . Ova of
Borbo lugens
, laid 20.ii.1990 by wild caught female, Cottar’s Camp, Masai Mara; photographed 22.ii.; eclosed 27.ii.; ref. 90/22.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The shelters of instar 3 caterpillars on
Panicum trichocladum
are made by rolling the distal portion of the leaf upwards ( 91 / 52 ), or downwards ( 90 /83, 95/103, 93/ 105 ) and feeding basally to this. An instar 4 caterpillar, probably of this species ( 95 / 111 ), on the same food plant, used a whole leaf rolled upwards to make a tight tube.
Henning et al . ( 1997 )
describe the caterpillar as feeding on the distal part of the leaf, but this may reflect the behaviour of older caterpillars.

Of the two individuals that I reared from ova ( 90 / 22 ), the male took six instars, while the female took five. The head capsules of the six instars of male measured 0.5 x 0.5 , 0.7 x 0.7 , 0.8 x 0.9 , 1.2 x 1.2 , 1.6 x 1.8 , 2.3 x 2.8mm wide x high, while those of the female measured 0.5 x 0.5 , 0.8 x 0.8 , 1.1 x 1.1 , 1.4 x 1.6 , 1.9 x 2.2mm . The average size of the final instar of other specimens was 2.1 x 2.4mm , so the sixth instar male was larger than this, while the fifth instar female was smaller. The first three instars have dark heads (
Figure 21
). As can be seen in
Figure 21
, the instar 3 caterpillar has a black transverse dorsal plate on T 1 , and Sevastopulo (unpublished) notes that this is present in the first four instars. Instars 3 and 4 have the body green with pale subdorsal and dorsolateral lines (
Figure 21
). The head of the instar
4 may
be intermediate to instar 5 which has variable head markings (
Figure 22
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 21 . Third instar caterpillar of
Borbo lugens
, reared from ovum (cf. Figure 20); moulted to instar 3 25.iii.1990; photographed 25.iii., 10mm; moulted to instar 4 29.iii–1.iv; ref. 90/22B.

subSubSection.paragraph: The mature caterpillar grows to 28mm ; head markings variable as described below; body pale yellowish green dorsally. Pale green ventrally; diffuse pale subdorsal and dorsolateral lines; spiracles pale; all legs paler than ground colour. The head is translucent green with variable dark markings and a broad white band down each side of the face. At the heavily marked extreme (Figure 22.2 ), there is a broad band from vertex laterally to mouthparts, a broad line each side of the epicranial suture, the adfrontals and clypeus dark, and a broad band from below the apex parallel to the epicranial suture which joins the adfrontal suture and runs to the mouthparts, almost obscuring the translucent green ground colour on the face. At the lightly marked extreme (Figure 22.4 ), the lateral line is narrower and only runs to the stemmata, the lines each side of the epicranial suture are very narrow, and only the upper part of the clypeal sutures are dark, leaving a broad band of translucent green ground colour down the centre of the face and across the adfrontals and clypeus, and the dark line down each epicranium is absent.

Round wax glands develop ventrolaterally on both segments A 7 and A 8 in the mature caterpillar ( 90 /22, 90/ 87 ). One caterpillar was noted as having the glands ventrolaterally on the posterior margin of A 6 and the anterior margin of A 7 , and narrowly on the posterior margin of A 7 and the anterior margin of A 8 ( 91 / 8 , Figure 22.1 ); another caterpillar had a broad gland on A 7 and a narrower one on anterior margin of A 8 ( 91 / 52 ). A caterpillar reared from eclosion took 44 days to pupation at Nairobi ( 90 / 22 A), while
Henning et al . ( 1997 )
report 40 days and one reared at the coast by Sevastopulo (unpublished) took 30 days.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 22 . Final instar caterpillars of
Borbo lugens
. 1 , lateral view with wax glands visible, collected 8.ii.1981 on
Panicum trichocladum
, Kisii; photographed 10.ii., 25mm; pupated 15.ii; ref. 91/8; 2 , detail of head with heavy markings, anterodorsal view; reared from ovum (cf. Figure 20); moulted to final instar 29.iii–1.iv; photographed 2.iv., 16 mm.; pupated 12.iv; ref. 90/ 22A; detail of head with medium markings, anterodorsolateral view; collected and photographed as (1); 4 , detail of head with light markings, anterodorsal view; collected as n-2 instar caterpillar 5.viii.1980 on
P. trichocladum , Kadera God Forest
, near Kisii; moulted to final instar 5–8.viii; photographed 21.viii., 22 mm; pupated 1.ix.; ref. 90/83B.

subSubSection.paragraph: Sevastopulo (unpublished) described a sixth instar caterpillar (which he considered unusual, and due to the dry condition of the food plant grasses. "Head whitish, a red-brown lateral stripe, the median suture with a brown line which divides and outlines the clypeus, and a very faint brown line on either side of the median suture...."

The life history illustrated by
Dickson & Kroon ( 1978 , Plate 33 )
shows a caterpillar with reduced dark head markings (only an inverted Y in the centre of the face) and extensive white areas, i.e. intermediate between Figures 22.3 and 22.4 .

The pupa is typical of the grass feeding members of this group. It is formed in a slightly folded blade of grass, the cremaster held in a silk bar, and supported by a silk girdle (Sevastopulo unpublished; Figure 23.1 ). Pupa 90 / 83 , reared from a caterpillar on
P. trichocladum
, was 24mm long; light green; a yellow-white subdorsal line on abdomen; the proboscis sheath extended about 5cm beyond the wing cases, half way to the cremaster tip. I noted that the eyes developing within the pupa turn dark without going through a red stage ( 90 / 22 ). Pupation takes 8–18 days.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 23 . Pupae of
Borbo lugens
. 1 , dorsolateral view; collected as final instar caterpillar 8.ii.1981 on
Panicum trichocladum
, Kisii; pupated 15.ii; photographed 19.ii., 23mm; adult female 27.ii.; ref. 91/8; 2 , dorsal view, collected as n-2 instar caterpillar 5.viii.1980 on
P. trichocladum
, Kadera God Forest
, near Kisii; pupated 1.ix.; photographed 2.ix., 24 mm; adult male 19.ix; ref. 90/83B.

subSubSection.paragraph:
A final instar caterpillar found on
Megathyrsus maximus
at Karen, Nairobi,
18 Sep 1988
( 88 / 82 ) and provisionally identified as this species, was attacked by larvae of a eulophid ectoparasitoid. The naked pupae were subsequently formed in the leaf shelter and took nine days to complete development, producing one male and
11 females
. A third instar caterpillar, collected with others on
P. trichocladum
at Kadera God Forest, near Kisii,
5 Aug 1990
( 90 / 83 A) moulted before becoming mummified; an adult wasp subsequently emerged (unnamed specimen in NHM).
